segment.source: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component
segment.target: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component

segment.source: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.
segment.target: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.

segment.source: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component
segment.target: Distributing a managed Windows Runtime Component

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: \[Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\]

segment.source: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.
segment.target: You can distribute your Windows Runtime Component by file copy.

segment.source: However, if your component consists of many files, installation can be tedious for your users.
segment.target: However, if your component consists of many files, installation can be tedious for your users.

segment.source: Also, errors in placing files or failure to set references might cause problems for them.
segment.target: Also, errors in placing files or failure to set references might cause problems for them.

segment.source: You can package a complex component as a Visual Studio extension SDK, to make it easy to install and use.
segment.target: You can package a complex component as a Visual Studio extension SDK, to make it easy to install and use.

segment.source: Users only need to set one reference for the entire package.
segment.target: Users only need to set one reference for the entire package.

segment.source: They can easily locate and install your component by using the Extensions and Updates dialog box, as described in Finding and Using Visual Studio Extensions, in the MSDN Library.
segment.target: They can easily locate and install your component by using the Extensions and Updates dialog box, as described in Finding and Using Visual Studio Extensions, in the MSDN Library.

segment.source: Planning a distributable Windows Runtime Component
segment.target: Planning a distributable Windows Runtime Component

segment.source: Choose unique names for binary files, such as your .winmd files.
segment.target: Choose unique names for binary files, such as your .winmd files.

segment.source: We recommend the following format to ensure uniqueness:
segment.target: We recommend the following format to ensure uniqueness:

segment.source: Your binary files will be installed in app packages, possibly with binary files from other developers.
segment.target: Your binary files will be installed in app packages, possibly with binary files from other developers.

segment.source: See "Extension SDKs" in How to: Create a Software Development Kit, in the MSDN Library.
segment.target: See "Extension SDKs" in How to: Create a Software Development Kit, in the MSDN Library.

segment.source: To decide how to distribute your component, consider how complex it is.
segment.target: To decide how to distribute your component, consider how complex it is.

segment.source: An extension SDK or similar package manager is recommended when:
segment.target: An extension SDK or similar package manager is recommended when:

segment.source: Your component consists of multiple files.
segment.target: Your component consists of multiple files.

segment.source: You provide versions of your component for multiple platforms (x86 and ARM, for example).
segment.target: You provide versions of your component for multiple platforms (x86 and ARM, for example).

segment.source: You provide both debug and release versions of your component.
segment.target: You provide both debug and release versions of your component.

segment.source: Your component has files and assemblies that are used only at design time.
segment.target: Your component has files and assemblies that are used only at design time.

segment.source: An extension SDK is particularly useful if more than one of the above are true.
segment.target: An extension SDK is particularly useful if more than one of the above are true.

segment.source: Note For complex components, the NuGet package management system offers an open source alternative to extension SDKs.
segment.target: Note For complex components, the NuGet package management system offers an open source alternative to extension SDKs.

segment.source: Like extension SDKs, NuGet enables you to create packages that simplify the installation of complex components.
segment.target: Like extension SDKs, NuGet enables you to create packages that simplify the installation of complex components.

segment.source: For a comparison of NuGet packages and Visual Studio extension SDKs, see Adding References Using NuGet Versus an Extension SDK in the MSDN Library.
segment.target: For a comparison of NuGet packages and Visual Studio extension SDKs, see Adding References Using NuGet Versus an Extension SDK in the MSDN Library.

segment.source: Distribution by file copy
segment.target: Distribution by file copy

segment.source: If your component consists of a single .winmd file, or a .winmd file and a resource index (.pri) file, you can simply make the .winmd file available for users to copy.
segment.target: If your component consists of a single .winmd file, or a .winmd file and a resource index (.pri) file, you can simply make the .winmd file available for users to copy.

segment.source: Users can put the file wherever they want to in a project, use the Add Existing Item dialog box to add the .winmd file to the project, and then use the Reference Manager dialog box to create a reference.
segment.target: Users can put the file wherever they want to in a project, use the Add Existing Item dialog box to add the .winmd file to the project, and then use the Reference Manager dialog box to create a reference.

segment.source: If you include a .pri file or an .xml file, instruct users to place those files with the .winmd file.
segment.target: If you include a .pri file or an .xml file, instruct users to place those files with the .winmd file.

segment.source: Note Visual Studio always produces a .pri file when you build your Windows Runtime Component, even if your project doesn't include any resources.
segment.target: Note Visual Studio always produces a .pri file when you build your Windows Runtime Component, even if your project doesn't include any resources.

segment.source: If you have a test app for your component, you can determine whether the .pri file is used by examining the contents of the app package in the bin\\debug\\AppX folder.
segment.target: If you have a test app for your component, you can determine whether the .pri file is used by examining the contents of the app package in the bin\\debug\\AppX folder.

segment.source: If the .pri file from your component doesn't appear there, you don't need to distribute it.
segment.target: If the .pri file from your component doesn't appear there, you don't need to distribute it.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can use the MakePRI.exe tool to dump the resource file from your Windows Runtime Component project.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can use the MakePRI.exe tool to dump the resource file from your Windows Runtime Component project.

segment.source: For example, in the Visual Studio Command Prompt window, type: makepri dump /if MyComponent.pri /of MyComponent.pri.xml You can read more about .pri files in Resource Management System (Windows).
segment.target: For example, in the Visual Studio Command Prompt window, type: makepri dump /if MyComponent.pri /of MyComponent.pri.xml You can read more about .pri files in Resource Management System (Windows).

segment.source: Distribution by extension SDK
segment.target: Distribution by extension SDK

segment.source: A complex component usually includes Windows resources, but see the note about detecting empty .pri files in the previous section.
segment.target: A complex component usually includes Windows resources, but see the note about detecting empty .pri files in the previous section.

segment.source: To create an extension SDK
segment.target: To create an extension SDK

segment.source: Make sure you have the Visual Studio SDK installed.
segment.target: Make sure you have the Visual Studio SDK installed.

segment.source: You can download the Visual Studio SDK from the Visual Studio Downloads page.
segment.target: You can download the Visual Studio SDK from the Visual Studio Downloads page.

segment.source: Create a new project using the VSIX Project template.
segment.target: Create a new project using the VSIX Project template.

segment.source: You can find the template under Visual C# or Visual Basic, in the Extensibility category.
segment.target: You can find the template under Visual C# or Visual Basic, in the Extensibility category.

segment.source: This template is installed as part of the Visual Studio SDK.
segment.target: This template is installed as part of the Visual Studio SDK.

segment.source: (Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C# or Visual Basic or Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C++, demonstrates the use of this template in a very simple scenario.
segment.target: (Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C# or Visual Basic or Walkthrough: Creating an SDK using C++, demonstrates the use of this template in a very simple scenario.

segment.source: Determine the folder structure for your SDK.
segment.target: Determine the folder structure for your SDK.

segment.source: The folder structure begins at the root level of your VSIX project, with the References, Redist, and DesignTime folders.
segment.target: The folder structure begins at the root level of your VSIX project, with the References, Redist, and DesignTime folders.

segment.source: References is the location for binary files that your users can program against.
segment.target: References is the location for binary files that your users can program against.

segment.source: The extension SDK creates references to these files in your users' Visual Studio projects.
segment.target: The extension SDK creates references to these files in your users' Visual Studio projects.

segment.source: Redist is the location for other files that must be distributed with your binary files, in apps that are created by using your component.
segment.target: Redist is the location for other files that must be distributed with your binary files, in apps that are created by using your component.

segment.source: DesignTime is the location for files that are used only when developers are creating apps that use your component.
segment.target: DesignTime is the location for files that are used only when developers are creating apps that use your component.

segment.source: In each of these folders, you can create configuration folders.
segment.target: In each of these folders, you can create configuration folders.

segment.source: The permitted names are debug, retail, and CommonConfiguration.
segment.target: The permitted names are debug, retail, and CommonConfiguration.

segment.source: The CommonConfiguration folder is for files that are the same whether they're used by retail or debug builds.
segment.target: The CommonConfiguration folder is for files that are the same whether they're used by retail or debug builds.

segment.source: If you're only distributing retail builds of your component, you can put everything in CommonConfiguration and omit the other two folders.
segment.target: If you're only distributing retail builds of your component, you can put everything in CommonConfiguration and omit the other two folders.

segment.source: In each configuration folder, you can provide architecture folders for platform-specific files.
segment.target: In each configuration folder, you can provide architecture folders for platform-specific files.

segment.source: If you use the same files for all platforms, you can supply a single folder named neutral.
segment.target: If you use the same files for all platforms, you can supply a single folder named neutral.

segment.source: You can find details of the folder structure, including other architecture folder names, in How to: Create a Software Development Kit, in the MSDN Library.
segment.target: You can find details of the folder structure, including other architecture folder names, in How to: Create a Software Development Kit, in the MSDN Library.

segment.source: (That article discusses both platform SDKs and extension SDKs.
segment.target: (That article discusses both platform SDKs and extension SDKs.

segment.source: You may find it useful to collapse the section about platform SDKs, to avoid confusion.
segment.target: You may find it useful to collapse the section about platform SDKs, to avoid confusion.

segment.source: Create an SDK manifest file.
segment.target: Create an SDK manifest file.

segment.source: The manifest specifies name and version information, the architectures your SDK supports, .NET Framework versions, and other information about the way Visual Studio uses your SDK.
segment.target: The manifest specifies name and version information, the architectures your SDK supports, .NET Framework versions, and other information about the way Visual Studio uses your SDK.

segment.source: You can find details and an example in How to: Create a Software Development Kit.
segment.target: You can find details and an example in How to: Create a Software Development Kit.

segment.source: Build and distribute the extension SDK.
segment.target: Build and distribute the extension SDK.

segment.source: For in-depth information, including localizing and signing the VSIX package, see VSIX Deployment in the MSDN Library.
segment.target: For in-depth information, including localizing and signing the VSIX package, see VSIX Deployment in the MSDN Library.
